data.title: Support more languages with new node-spellchecker
data.body:
For years users who write non-english texts are desperatey waiting for spell checking in more languages than only English.

[From the bugtracker of node-spellchecker](https://github.com/atom/node-spellchecker/issues/4) I guess that everything is ready to get into Atom.

So please make non-english speakers happy.

data.title: Document tree in navigator panel cut off while a lot of files shown
data.body: Atom 1.4.3 for Mac

data.title: Switching tabs restarts nodemon
data.body:
Here is the corresponding issue on the Nodemon repo: https://github.com/remy/nodemon/issues/770

Basically whenever I switch tabs with `nodemon` running in the same project directory, it detects a file change and restarts the given process.

data.title: Text flickering since 1.4.3 update
data.body:
Hi all,

I just updated all my packages and Atom to 1.4.3, I'm running on Archlinux with i3wm, node v5.5.0, npm: v3.7.1 and having a strange issue.

When I scroll down the code it happens that the code looks like it's duplicated. When I click in the area, the text is fine again.

![flicker](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3389462/12847810/2c67e80a-cc16-11e5-8d6c-3b8a24c5f67b.png)

The same also happens in tree view.

Strange thing is that I tried downgrading to 1.3 and it doesn't work either. Tried deleting the .atom folder in my home, but nothing changed.

I'm gonna try the latest beta too, to see if it works.

Any idea?
Thanks in advance.

data.title: Proposal: API enhancement for editors with block decorations
data.body:
I fiddled with the block decoration features to check how this would affect the minimap and as I suspected it completely breaks the sync between the two views.

The biggest concern I have for the moment is that there is no public API to get the height and the y position of a line with a block decoration attached. Since I guess these are quite costly operations that are already handled by the editor's view I would expect it to expose these informations publicly so that we don't need to traverse all the editor's layers and decorations to compute these values. 

Another approach would be to have two sets of scroll values, one that account for the decorations and one that doesn't. For instance with a block decoration of 100px height at one line, the first method would return a scroll height equal to the height of all lines + 100 and the other one would return the just the height of all lines. Same goes for the scroll position, the first one would returns the scroll as it's used in the view, the other one would return the scroll position ignoring the block decoration (clamping the value to the start/end y of the line depending on whether the block is displayed before or after the line).

A third possibility is to have a scroll position defined as a couple of value: the first visible line index and a position within the line (in the range 0-1). If we have access to the line y position and height through an API, we can compute the corresponding scroll top, or map this to any other type of grid and still be in complete sync with the editor.

Another concern for the minimap is that block decorations breaks the assumption that an editor's lines all fit on a predefined grid. It means that I can no longer use a ratio to transpose a line height and position and still get an integer value at the end - let say a line takes 17px in the editor, and 3px in the minimap, I can always assume that line 11 will be at y=30px in the minimap. Now with block decorations, a line can have an arbitrary height, which means that if I apply this ratio to get the line height I'll probably end up with a decimal value. And as the minimap is using a canvas, decimal values need to be avoided at all cost to preserve the crispness of the minimap render. To workaround that I would probably need to map every line heights from the editor to a rounded value more suited to the minimap. But same thing here, it would better if I could avoid traversing all the editor's lines to make this computations. 

How do you feel about this?

cc/ @nathansobo, @as-cii

data.title: atom hangs on opening one specific folder only
data.body:
I have a project in pwd, and I usually open atom using:

```
atom -n .
```

It hung once and I had to kill it and now it won't open in this dir unless I use --safe.

What can I do to log details about what's making it hang?

Or, what can I do to clear out whatever state is saved about this project that's making it hang?

I tried using --log <file> and nothing is logged, the log file is not even created.

data.title: Snippet adds extra spaces if the snippet starts with spaces
data.body:
The fix will probably have to be hard-coded, but here's the issue:

If you have a snippet with a body like this:
`$1.$2 = function ($3) {\n\t\n\t$4\n\t\n};`
It works fine. But, if your snippet has a space directly after a selector ($):
`$1 = function ($2) {\n\t\n\t$3\n\t\n};`
Then the whole block of lines of code all get a space inside the tabs.

Presumably also occurs if the snippet starts with a space.

data.title: Fix Javascript-related specs
data.body:
These specs broke yesterday after Atom was updated to use `language-javascript@0.109.0`.  That version provided further control over numbers by splitting hex/octal/decimal numbers into different tokens.  Normal numbers are now `constant.numeric.decimal` instead of `constant.numeric`.

Will merge once specs are green.

data.title: atom is ignoring files that shouldn't be ignored
data.body:
atom is ignoring files that begin with a `test_` for me on Mac. eg. `test_function.js`. These files are greyed out in the tree-view sidebar, and my linter isn't linting these files.

If i go to atom -> packages -> tree-view -> settings, and check "hide VCS ignored files", `test_function.js` disappears from tree-view side bar.

Neither the `.gitignore` in the repo nor my `~/.gitignore_global` has have anything that matches `test_*`. I ran git check-ignore in the working directory to see what rules git was applying from where.

```
$ git check-ignore -v *
<user>/.gitignore_global:7:**/_*    _tmp
.gitignore:1:node_modules/  node_modules

$ git status
On branch master
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/master'.
Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

    test_function.js
```

Curiously, git status _is_ tracking the same file.

It seems that there isn't anything that would cause `test_*` to be ignored by atom, yet it is. The effect seems to be global. I've tried adding similar files to other repos and viewing the directory structure in atom, and atom ignores them everywhere.

Is there anything else I can do to find a cause ?

data.title: Could you guys stop expanding text?
data.body:
`input[tab]` in php html expands to `<input type="button" name="name" value="">`

You're just randomly guessing what I want and I end up having to delete it. Why not just expand to `<input>`?

data.title: Keep spaces vs tabs setting according to last used?
data.body:
When I toggle tabs/spaces in the editor, it works fine for the current file, but then I open a new file and it resets.

Is there a setting or way to keep the setting until I change it again?

The reason I ask is because I have to adhere to WPCS (tabs) during the workday, and in my free time I work on open source stuff and prefer 2 spaces. So it's just a pain having to go into config a few times every day instead of just being able to set this via the command palette.

data.title: "Ignored Names" in Preferences has no effect in TreeView
data.body:
The list of ignored names in the preferences don't have any effect in the TreeView. Letting it to the defaults still shows files/directories like .git, Thumbs.db and the such. Even explicitly defining these has no effect.
Starting atom in safe-mode did not help.
The error is there since I installed it in the first place and I didn't bother to report it until now.

OS: OSX 10.10.5
Atom build: 1.4.3 (official build from website)
Installed additional community packages:
- git-plus
- plantuml-viewer
- vim-mode

I've attached a screenshot. Anything else I need to provide?
![bildschirmfoto 2016-02-04 um 13 41 38](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/350047/12815347/35b88930-cb46-11e5-8585-c31c4dc2d30a.png)
Thanks, Alex.

data.title: Show CPU usage for each package
data.body:
I'm stuck with an Atom that [constantly hangs](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10159) (CPU at 100%) and I suspect the cause being an installed package.

I'd like to see the CPU usage of the each package's Atom Helper. 
My suggestion would be, in `Settings/Installed Packages`, for each installed and enabled package show the correspondent Atom Helper CPU usage.

It would be ok to have these numbers updated only when I first open Settings/Installed Packages, no need to have them update in real time.

Another viable option would be to assign names to Atom Helpers, so that I can see the offending package name by inspecting the Activity Monitor.
For example:

![screen shot 2016-02-04 at 13 20 39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1309648/12814811/313b4086-cb42-11e5-8415-bf3b045de00b.png)

-> what package is associated with the hanging Atom Helper?

data.title: Atom profiles
data.body:
I'm stuck with an Atom that [constantly hangs](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10159) (CPU at 100%) and I'd like to try to disable packages iteratively to track this problem down.

This makes me think that when you have a similar problem in Firefox the suggested approach is to disable all addons manually or just use a clean profile.

Disabling all packages is problematic as I keep some package installed but disabled for future testing, hence disabling a package I use just to inspect an Atom problem would send it to the list of Disabled packages, which makes it difficult to find it again in a long list of greyed out packages.

Instead, running Atom with a "clean" profile would let me quickly check if the problem persists, it would be much more powerful.

Hello guys,
